title: Brocket Hall Walks

images.title: Bikeboy / Brocket Hall
images.caption: Brocket Hall. Built in 1760, replacing an earlier buildings of 1239 and 1430.

images.title: Ian Capper, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: A swan takes off from The Broadwater, an artificial lake on the River Lea, with Brocket Hall behind. Brocket Hall was built by James Paine in 1760, although there had been two previous buildings on the site, the first dating from 1239. It was the home of two Prime Ministers, Lord Melbourne and Lord Palmerston, who died at Brocket in 1865 while in office. It was later the home of the Baronets Brocket, the third Baronet converting it into a hotel, which is its current use. It is grade I listed.

images.title: Ian Capper / Paine Bridge, Brocket Park
images.caption: Palladian bridge at Brocket Hall. The Paine Bridge, viewed above the weir across the River Lea which forms The Broadwater. The bridge dates from 1772-4 and was built by James Paine, who also built Brocket Hall, visible through the main arch.

images.title: Michael Trolove / Brocket Hall
images.caption: Viewed from the footpath that winds its way through the estate grounds.

images.title: Christine Matthews / Clockhouse Building at Brocket Hall, Hatfield, Hertfordshire
images.caption: Clockhouse Building

images.title: Christine Matthews / Grounds of Brocket Hall, Hatfield, Hertfordshire
images.caption: Hall Grounds. This stately home is used for functions. There is also a golf course in the grounds.

description: This circular walk takes you along the public footpaths surrounding Brocket Hall in Welwyn Garden City in Hertfordshire. You'll pass around the beautiful estate, passing Lemsford and Cromer Hyde with woodland and country trails to enjoy. You can also visit the estate for afternoon tea though you must reserve in advance. See the link for more information. In the park there's nice walks along the Broadwater Lake and the River Lea with a fine 18th century Palladian bridge to cross on the way. The estate is also good for wildlife with Buzzards and Red Kites to look out for. Part of this route uses a section of the Lea Valley Walk .  You could extend your walk by following the waymarked trail west towards Wheathampstead . Head south east and you will soon come to the Lemsford Springs Nature Reserve.
